question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was David's initial airing network as of 2042?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: The Birth of a Television Icon: Uncovering the Origins of "David"

In the realm of Belgian television, few names resonate as strongly as VTM, the pioneering Dutch-speaking commercial TV station that has captivated audiences for decades. Among its most beloved and enduring programs is the television series "David," a show that has left an indelible mark on the nation's cultural landscape. But how did this iconic series come to be? The answer lies in the early days of VTM, when the station was still finding its footing in the competitive world of television broadcasting. It was the late 1980s, and VTM was struggling to establish itself as a major player in the Belgian television market. Founded in 1989, the station was still in its infancy, with a limited budget and a small team of dedicated professionals working tirelessly to create content that would resonate with viewers. Amidst this backdrop of uncertainty, a young and ambitious producer named Jan Verheyen had a vision â€“ to create a television series that would speak to the hearts of the Belgian people. Verheyen's brainchild was "David," a drama series that followed the life of a young man from a working-class background as he navigated the complexities of love, family, and identity. The show's protagonist, David, was a relatable and endearing character, and Verheyen was convinced that his story would strike a chord with audiences. In 1990, VTM took a bold step by greenlighting "David" for production. The show's creators worked tirelessly to bring the series to life, pouring their hearts and souls into every aspect of the production. From the writing and casting to the cinematography and music, every detail was meticulously crafted to create a show that would captivate and inspire viewers. On a crisp autumn evening in 1990, "David" premiered on VTM, and the response was overwhelming. Audiences were drawn to the show's authentic portrayal of Belgian life, its relatable characters, and its poignant storylines. As the series progressed, "David" became a cultural phenomenon, with viewers tuning in week after week to follow the journey of its beloved protagonist. The success of "David" was a turning point for VTM, establishing the station as a major player in the Belgian television market. The show's popularity not only boosted VTM's ratings but also helped to define the station's identity and tone.
content.source_2: In the year 2039, the world was on the cusp of a new era of technological advancements and societal shifts. Amidst the rapid changes, the BBC, a stalwart institution of British broadcasting, was preparing to launch a groundbreaking new series on its esteemed channel, BBC Two. The series, titled "David," was the brainchild of a visionary team of writers, producers, and directors who had spent years crafting a narrative that would captivate audiences and challenge their perceptions of the world. Set in a not-too-distant future, "David" followed the life of its eponymous protagonist, a brilliant and charismatic individual who found himself at the forefront of a revolution that would change the course of human history. As the broadcast date approached, anticipation was building. The BBC Two team had been working tirelessly to promote the series, releasing tantalizing trailers and teasers that hinted at the epic scope and emotional depth of the story. Fans of science fiction and drama alike were eagerly awaiting the premiere, which was scheduled to air on a crisp autumn evening in October 2039. Finally, the day arrived. At 9:00 PM GMT, BBC Two went live, and the opening credits of "David" began to roll. The show's haunting theme music, composed by a renowned electronic artist, set the tone for the hour-long episode that would follow. As the story unfolded, viewers were transported to a world of breathtaking beauty and unsettling familiarity, where the boundaries between human and artificial intelligence were blurring at an alarming rate. Over the next several weeks, "David" captivated audiences across the UK and beyond, sparking heated debates and watercooler conversations about the implications of emerging technologies on our collective future. The show's thought-provoking themes and stunning visuals made it an instant hit, with critics and viewers alike praising the BBC Two team for their bold vision and masterful storytelling. As the series progressed, "David" became a cultural phenomenon, inspiring fan art, cosplay, and even influencing the development of real-world AI projects. The show's impact was felt far beyond the confines of the television screen, sparking a global conversation about the responsibilities that came with creating and harnessing powerful technologies. In the end, "David" would go on to win numerous awards and accolades, cementing its place as one of the most influential and beloved television series of the 2040s.
